segments.text: This is Sunday morning, May 7, a bright, clear day.
And I'm heading toward Kerrville for an interview with Porter Garner, Jr.,
who for many years operated the Cadillac bar in Laredo.
He is now retired and I'm going to interview him this afternoon and then go to a meeting of the Schreiner College Board of Directors tomorrow in Kerrville.
This is an effort to try to begin to record some of my memories
Of service here at Texas A&M.
Which began in the fall of 1959.
My parents.
We're both.
What they identified as quote farm kids.
From near Garland.
Texas.
When they were born, dad in 1909 and mother in 1910, that was a little farming community about 20 miles northeast of Dallas.
And the money crop for everyone was cotton.
They were both from what they identified as
hard working farm families.
They married in 1930 and I was born then a year later in 1931.
Dad became a construction carpenter when the war started.
He got a job with the construction crew that created Shepherd Air Force Base up in Wichita Falls, S-H-E-P-P-A-R-D. And we moved up there in June of 1941.
We were there until about Halloween and then
went to Fort Smith, Arkansas, where he had the same task at what we called Camp Chaffee, C-H-A-F-F-E-E, an army base.
After a lot of flooding and what we thought was cold weather, he heard about better pay down at
shipyard in Orange, Texas, the extreme southeastern corner of the state.
We headed down there, and he was hired as a shipwright, S-H-I-P-W-R-I-G-H-T, which we soon learned meant someone who did woodwork
in relation to ships.
The pay there was $1.12 and a half cents an hour.
And since he had been making 25 cents an hour on construction in the Garland area less than two years earlier, we thought that gold had been discovered.

We lived first in a little two-room apartment out toward what we called the Port Arthur Bridge, a very high rainbow-shaped structure across the Natchez River, N-A-C-H-E-S, until near the end of the spring semester.

I was a sixth grader and had entered a four-teacher, eight-grade school in January 1942, the day the school district changed from the Prairie View Common School District to the Bridge City Independent District.
Late that spring, mother and dad bought a 29-foot house trailer
and were able to park it in the backyard of a nice family, A.C. Griffith, Abby, and Freda, F-R-E-D-A-B-B-E-Y, F-R-E-D-A, Abby and Freda Griffith, at 15, uh-uh.
the southeast corner of Green and Main Street of 16th and Main Street in Orange.
I finished the year at Bridge City.

And then early that summer, mother came back from the wash interior one day saying that she had learned that there was a rich man in Orange named Lutcher Stark who paid for almost all of the expenses of the high school boys band, the Bengal Lancers.
and the girls drum and bugle corps, the Bengal Guards.
He bought the instruments, the music, the uniforms, paid the travel expenses, and even underwrote salary for the band director, a man named Frank W.R. Hubert.
In order to be in the band, you had to
get permission of Mr. Huber.
So mother took me over to visit with him very soon.
And he quickly asked what instrument I wanted to play.
I told him trumpet because I was a fan of Harry James, who'd grown up not far west in Beaumont, not far west of Orange.
He quickly asked to see.
For me to.
Show him that gap in my upper teeth.
Smiled and said.
That trumpet would not work, but I needed to be a clarinet player.
So I began practicing then.
And as school started that fall, I got to March with.
The Bengal anchors.
which other than me was made up of some really fine musicians and we became a really good marching group.
We lived in that trailer where there were couches at each end that unfolded into double width
It had a sink and an electric refrigerator, but we went into the back porch of the Griffiths' house for restroom and bathing facilities.
Orange was in the midst of going from 7,000 to about 40,000
population in 18 months because of the boom of three shipyards.
Dad was working at a consolidated shipyard, a big operation, which built destroyers, for instance, DDs, destroyer escorts, for instance, DEs,
and landing craft infantry, LCIs.
The classes at the high school building, a structure designed for four grades and 500 students.
But
Having to accommodate six grades and almost 3,000 students were really hectic.
There were classes in the hallway and the school cafeteria and everyone had to stand in line to go to the restroom.
Yet we had some splendid teachers and everything seemed orderly.
In hindsight, it is astonishing how crime-free that boomtown was as we listened at the news from Europe and the Pacific in what seemed to us to be some very tough years, some very tough months.

After perhaps two years in the trailer house, we were able to move to the Riverside Edition, a newly created government housing project northeast of the older part of Orange, which was created out of a swamp.

The construction of Riverside had come about when engineers went in and cut down the cypress trees in the swamp, quickly pumped sand out of the Sabine River, and then put prefab housing on that location to accommodate perhaps 10,000 residents.
It was big enough that there were three elementary schools just to serve Riverside.
By the fall of 1943, the new high school for Urange had opened just east of what had been the old high school.
The new high school named in honor of Mr. Stark, Stark High School.
with Tigers as the traditional mascot name and orange and black the school colors.
The old high school building became Helen Carr Junior High in honor of the longtime high school principal.
But still, the Bengal Guards and Lancers included students from both institutions.
During those years, we had quickly joined the First Presbyterian Church there and once more encountered the generosity of the Stark family.
H.J.
Lutcher Stark's mother,
had financed the construction of the splendid pink granite building for the First Presbyterian Church down at 8th and Green Avenue.
It was built in the first decade of the century at a very high cost for that era.
and included some prize winning windows, stained glass windows that she had bought at the Chicago World's Fair.
Even at church, some of us played in a little band and we learned that Mr. Stark's idea for the Bengal Guards and Lancers had started
with the band that a little musical organization that he had helped underwrite in the mid-1930s.
The Reverend E.T.
Drake was the longtime minister at the church.
Having started his
ministry there as a student, a palestine student at the Austin Presbyterian Seminary.
It was the only congregation he ever served and he did so with great dignity.
Another distinction of that building is that it was the first air-conditioned building west of the Mississippi and perhaps the first in the world.
The Stark family, once more, the Stark family had underwritten the construction of an ice making plant in a building just north of the church sanctuary.
Then fans blew air over the blocks of ice through a duct system into the church building.
Life in that boomtown was hectic, was calm, but always in high gear.
The shipyard went for many months, worked three shifts, and included a lot of overtime.
The launchings of the destroyers in particular were major times of major celebration.
And we proudly listened to victory on the radio from the European
and Pacific theaters.
Particularly, I remember D-Day, June 6, 1944.
We were driving up to Garland to visit family.
I kept the radio on almost all the trip in the car.
And then my grandmother Jackson, mother's mother, my maternal grandmother Jackson,

allowed me to sleep on a pallet in the living room of her farmhouse, and put the radio right down by my pallet, and I listened about almost all night to reports of the victory the Americans were attaining.
Back at school, as I moved forward into grades, I became active in a number of organizations,

In hindsight, it is clear that one of the key teachers that blessed me was Myrta Mae Force, M-Y-R-T-A, M-A-E, two words, Myrta Mae Force, a first-year teacher that all of us thought was strikingly beautiful, who had just graduated from LSU.
She organized a group of us into what she called a debating club.
And we quite often gathered on Saturdays to go picnic and to learn more about public speaking and debating.
In retrospect, it is clear that what she was really doing was giving a few of us, perhaps a dozen, encouragement in public speaking and organization of our thoughts.
She helped this country boy, this small town boy,
to believe that he had capability.
She also was a ceaseless encourager of hard work and high grades.
That paragraph, that encouragement put her back in the category of two other teachers
who had already been very important in my development.
The first of these was Miss Faye Strange, third grade instructor in Garland, with prematurely white hair,
Because she had prematurely white hair, we students thought that she must have been very aged.
In hindsight, it is now clear that she was in her 30s, but she took this
this hesitant country boy who had never, who had not been aware of any encouragement from anyone other than family before Miss Strange became his teacher.
She gave me hope that I could do well, and my grades improved sharply.
And she made a lifelong impression on my effort.
I will always be grateful that I had the opportunity at my parents 50th wedding anniversary to thank her in person for her contribution at that celebration.
And then not long before her death in
early in the year 2000.
I wrote her in an effort to put on paper my heartfelt feelings.
Paragraph a second teacher who was important in
The development of intellectual confidence and talent was fourth-grader Mrs. Grace Glaze, G-L-E-Z-E.
Her husband was then the high school principal in Garland, and Mrs. Glaze had an unceasing determination to encourage everyone to do their best.
One of her favorite techniques was a series of competitions.
Spelling bee, writing, essays, themes, mathematics, travel.
In hindsight, it seems that she was trying to do everything she could to give every student an opportunity to be a winner.
I particularly remember that with the youngster named Jesse Cathy, C-A-T-H-E-Y.
Jesse's family was truly and pitifully poor.
Apparently, his clothes were not washed very often, nor did he bathe regularly.
He lacked polish and confidence, but the one thing he could do well was to write letters.
That was his handwriting.
It was very, very attractive.
almost as if he had had penmanship classes.
And so our writing contest quite often resulted in Jesse being the winner.
And there was his moment of glory.
For me, the great victory of that year in Mrs. Glaze's class was when the year's spelling bee ended, I was at the head of the line.
When you missed a day and your turn came, you then moved to the foot of the line when you returned.
I had been at the head of the line but then my parents and I took our first vacation ever to go to visit some of mother's relatives in Tennessee during the Easter break in 1941.
The only days
Only days of construction I missed, the first four years of school, except when I had the chicken pox soon after Christmas in the second grade.
But anyway, but still, when I came back, was able to work to the head of the line, and when the year was over, I was first in place, and that gave me as a trophy,
for being the, quote, champion speller.
A scrapbook filled with letters to Uncle Wiggly, to Uncle, or was it Uncle Ben, who wrote a column in the Weekly Reader, a publication aimed at elementary schools nationally.
But back to Orange.
Even in junior high, I began to take courses that might lead me toward college.
Never could I remember feeling that I would have any choice but to go to college.
Although neither parent had finished high school,
Dad dropping out in the 9th grade.
To to take a job quote on the square in Garland.
That employment with Cole and Davis, COLE and Davis.
The primary.
Quote quote dry goods store.
Quote in Garland ended during the Depression.
When they had to lay off everyone except family.
Mother had dropped out.
Had mother had had to drop out of school.
Early in the 11th grade.
Because of her mother's arthritis.
Her mother's rheumatism and she had to help take care of her.
And.
As the middle child of 11 children, mother then had to accept a number of almost parental responsibilities.
Because of those experiences, they always spoke to me with the phrase, quote, when you go to college, period, quote.
I did not feel I had a choice and did not question, but that their determination for me was a blessing.
Back in high school, I gradually became a member of a small group that took all of the courses leading toward college.
although we didn't know the phrase, quote, college prep then.
That meant taking two years of algebra, beginning algebra in the ninth grade, and completing the four years of math with what we called solid plane geometry, solid geometry, and trigonometry.
two years of Latin plus a year of Spanish, biology, physics, and chemistry.
During my last years, I tried to play football and run track, ending up as the quarterback of a truly undistinguished team.
We won one game beating Galveston Ball High Golden Tornadoes.
An unforgettable game because Billy Hempel, H-E-M-P-E-L, a linebacker for the Tornadoes in attempting to tackle our fullback,
